Description: Pottery bottle; greyish clay with pinkish-grey finish; occasional fine mica and frequent fine grits; rounded ridge below neck; tall conical body with flat base; edge of base knife-cut; small lug handle joining at ridge; body very irregular; mended from two fragments; rim missing.
Curator's comments: Of the same shape as Boston, MFA RES.86.117. Compare the two-handled vessels of similar shape, British Museum 1888,0601.729 and 730. The latter shape is common on Rhodes (e.g. Jacopi 1930, fig. 346; Jacopi 1933, 18-19, fig. 5, tomb II; Kinch 2014, pl. 42 no. 18.1, tomb 18; A. Coulié in Coulié and Filimonos-Tsopotou 2014, 235 no. 69). The version with the single handle recalls vessels found on Cyprus (e.g. Salamis). The production place(s) of these heavy bottles has not yet been determined but must be sought in the Eastern Mediterranean area. Coulié, A. and Filimonos-Tsopotou, M., Rhodes, une île grecque aux portes de l’Orient, Paris. Jacopi, G. 1930. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro I. Clara Rhodos IV. Scavi Nelle Necropoli Camiresi 1929-1930. Jacopi, G. 1933. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro II. Clara Rhodos 6-7. Kinch, K. F. 1914, Vroulia, Berlin.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (HB.03)
